Which city has more temples than Hyderabad?

Varanasi is the city that has more temples than Hyderabad.

Varanasi has more temples than Hyderabad. This is because Varanasi is one of the oldest cities in India and has been an important spiritual center for Hindus for centuries. For this reason, it is home to numerous ancient temples and monuments. It is also known as the religious capital of India.

This is because Varanasi is an ancient city that has been a center of Hindu pilgrimage for thousands of years. It is said to have over 2000 temples, while Hyderabad is estimated to have around 500 temples.

Varanasi is the city that has more temples than Hyderabad.

Varanasi has more temples than Hyderabad. This is because Varanasi is one of the oldest cities in India and has been an important spiritual center for Hindus for centuries. For this reason, it is home to numerous ancient temples and monuments. It is also known as the religious capital of India.

This is because Varanasi is an ancient city that has been a center of Hindu pilgrimage for thousands of years. It is said to have over 2000 temples, while Hyderabad is estimated to have around 500 temples.

It is home to some of the most important temples in Hinduism, including the Kashi Vishwanath Temple and the Tulsi Manas Temple.

The Birla Temple in Hyderabad is officially called the Sri Venkateswara (Balaji) Temple. It is a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Venkateswara, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, and is located in the heart of Hyderabad, in the neighborhood of Banjara Hills.

The temple is built by the Birla Foundation, a prominent Indian business conglomerate, and is known for its stunning architecture and elaborate carvings. It is a popular destination for Hindu devotees and visitors, and attracts a large number of visitors, especially during festivals and special events. The temple is surrounded by lush green gardens and offers a peaceful and serene atmosphere, making it an ideal place for prayer, meditation, and reflection.

What is so special about the Vemulawada temple? Why is it revered so much by many communities in many parts of Telangana?

Vemulawada or Lembula Vaatika ( Pronounced by various people as Vemulawaada or lemulawaada or Yemulawada or Yemulaada or Yemudaala) is an ancient and historical place in north central part of telugu country ( in Rajanna siricilla district, nearly 36 km west of present day Karimnagar city of Telangana and nearly 155 km north east of Hyderabad city), where the main deity - Sri Raaja Raajeshwara Swamy or Raajanna is greatly revered by people of many districts of not only Telangana, but also telugus from AP and other linguistic groups from neighboring states too! Vemulawada or Lembula Vaatika ( Pronounced by various people as Vemulawaada or lemulawaada or Yemulawada or Yemulaada or Yemudaala) is an ancient and historical place in north central part of telugu country ( in Rajanna siricilla district, nearly 36 km west of present day Karimnagar city of Telangana and nearly 155 km north east of Hyderabad city), where the main deity - Sri Raaja Raajeshwara Swamy or Raajanna is greatly revered by people of many districts of not only Telangana, but also telugus from AP and other linguistic groups from neighboring states too! It is one of the premier Saiva Kshetrams in South India and the most prominent HARI-HARA Kshetrams, signifying the abedha (unity) of Lord Siva and Lord Vishnu !!! It is one of the most visited and busiest temples of telugu land !!

(The dharmagundam, temple’s step well )

Etymology and basic History:

The word “Vemulawaaada” is believed to be derived from “Lembula vaatika”, which means a city or habitation of cow-calves !! This Lembula vatika has transformed into Lemulawada and later to “Vemulawada”

The Rajarajeshwara swamy Kshetram of Vemulawada has a great Puranic and Historic significance and a major center where Folk and Classical cultures have equally flourished (and flourishing). In fact,, Vemulawada temple and the town reached their zenith under the regime of Vemulwada Chalukyas, a branch of western chalukyas, who sided with Rashtrakutas !! After shifting capitals initially from Poudhanyapuram, present day Bodhan, to Gangadhara, near Kondagattu Hanuman temple, Vemulawada Chalukyas finally made Vemulawada as their capital city !! During the regime of Vemulawada Chalukyas , the city of Vemulawada has become a great center of learning for Sanskrit, Kannada and Telugu, though Sanskrit and Kannada received greater support from rulers, Telugu was the language of the masses of the land. Unlike Madurai Nayakars, who encouraged both telugu and tamizh while ruling in the heart of Madurai (as it was tamizh land), there is little information available regarding the encouragement of telugu by Chalukyas of Vemulawada.. This is surprising because, the regime was ruling in the heart of telugu land and telugu by then itself was sufficiently a well developed language (telugu was used in their epigraphs along with Kannada and Sanskrit)!! This still remains a kind of unexplored aspect in history. They used to give epigraphs in three langhuges- Sanskrit, Kannada and Telugu. In fact, their epigraphs in telugu, which contained telugu poems (some of them are the earliest avaliable telugu poems in Kanda meter), were some of the important evidences that helped in defending the classical status of telugu language.

Interestingly, it was an important centre of learning for both Vedic and non-Vedic scholars (Jaina, Baudhha) of Deccan region in pre-medieval India and now a major shrine only for Vedic/Hindu pantheon, but still visited by Buddhist and Jain disciples. During that era, Vemulawada is believed as one of the best places for Priests and Sanskrit pundits to live in.

Also, It is a major shrine of the telugu land that was under patronage of almost all Hindu Empires ruling the region till the fall of Kakatiyas. Later, it was on the feeble support of the local Zamindars.. Fascinatingly, this temple never ever got disruption in its daily rituals and visiting of devotees even during islamic rule after the fall of local hindu empires !!

During the days of Nizam, the local priests comprising 108 families, looked after the temple affairs and the town. They used to pay taxes to Nizam government which has no direct role in the governance. (Interestingly, famous Bhadrachalam temple, thousand pillar temple of Hanumakonda were under direct influence of Nizam government). Even now, the rituals in the temple are handled by archakas of 128 families.

Geographical uniqueness:

If you observe any of the famous temples , there will be some natural assets associated with it, either hill, mountain, river front, river bank, sea shore, or dense forest..

If not, it will be part of any big city.

Vemulawada doesn’t satisfy any of these, yet it is one of the most revered and most visited popular among ancient shrines!!

(the temple lake beside the temple, the left side building is kalyana katta/ hair tonsure hall, while the far right building in the background is the waiting/queueing hall of devotees)

Historic Importance:

Actually Vemulawada is a special bond like Hampi between Telugus and Kanndigas..

Just like how great Telugu poets and Kannda poets (and other languages too) thrived in Hampi jointly.

Much before Vjayangara, a small feudatory of Rashtrakutas ( western chalukyas), called Vemulawaada chalukyas have encouraged Kannada, Sanskrit poetry a lot in 740 AD to 1000 AD in heart of Telangana.The famous "Pampa" kavi of Kannada (one of Kannda 's Kavi trayam, trinity of Kannada literature ) had written Kannda Bharata in Vemulawada !! In those times people were almost telugu , but Kings were Kannada, hence telugu was used for epigraphs related to business and transactions.. along with Sanskirt, but Kannda and Sanskrit poetry got great encouragement, while there is less information regarding encouragement of telugu poetry.. But, even telugu poets used to write in Kannada for official recognition. The capital of Vemulawada Chalukyas was Vemulawada..

Also, the author of oldest available telugu literature piece “Kvijanasrayam” is written by the famous sweet poet called Malliya Rechana of Vemulawada..

Vemulawada was considered as the best place for learned scholars during those times. By then itself it had four major telugu poets (nearly contemporary to Nannaya), -Malliya rechana, Bheema kavi, Jinavallabha, Pampa kavi,etc !!

It is not only an important pilgrimage for Vedic religions, but also an important centre for Jainism and Buddhism along with local folk traditions. You can find lots of relics of jainism and buddhism in the city. And till date, pilgrims from both Jainism and Buddhism do visit Vemulwada .

You will even find the reference to many deities whose name and lineage is not yet decoded.

The temple stands also as an example of India’s secular tradition , with a dargah of muslim devotee inside main temple complex. It is a place of Saiva, Vaishnava, Jaina, Buddist, and even Islam !!

In Telugu Literature:

Being one of the important and great pilgrimage centers in telugu land , it is often referred as "Dakshina Kasi" (Beneras of South) & "Maha Kshetram" (great pilgrimage) and “Rajarajeshwara Kshetram” in Telugu Literature.

In telugu language’s first travel documentary, “Kasi Yatra Charitra”, by Enugula Veeraswamayya, written in 1831, had mentions of Vemulawada, when he is on the way to Kamareddy town from Hyderabad. He mentions it as “Maha kshetram” (the grand pilgrim centre). It also mentions about Vemulawada bhemma kavi associated with this temple town , whose legend is well known in telugu literary circles for over a millennium.

See the following excerpt from Kashi Yatra Charitra book..

Until recently, it was opined that bathukamma festival was started during Kakatiya era or Qutubshahi era. Recent historical findings from historians based in Telangana found that there is strong historical link to Vemulawada for the festival. Parantaka Chozha knowing about the “bola shakara” of this Kshetra, has taken an oath that he will name his son after the deity of Vemulawada, Sri RajaRajeswara (because by then itself , it was one of the most revered temples of Deccan region .. and hence he named his son as “Raja Raja chozha”. This Raja Raja chozha after winning over rashtrakutas , had even defeated Vemulwada chalukyas (as they sided with rashtrakutas) and has taken the jwels , wealth and great Siva linga of Vemulwada to Thanjavur.. Epigraph by Arikesari , last ruler of Vemulawada chalukyan rule, mentions this. Even now there are striking similarities with Vemulwada’s Bhimeswara alayam and Thanjavur Brihadiswara alayam.. But as Parvati, Brihadeswari devi is left out , to pacify her, women folk used to prepare floral arrangements and sing songs to express their protest to chozhas !! This is the starting point of Bathukamma festival as per history , but local versions have many puranic and folk lineages. Even in most of these versions, there is a mention of Chozha kings and kingdom.

(Bathukamma festival is celebrated for 7 days in Vemulawada as against norm of 9 days in rest of Telangana and parts of AP).

Architecture and sculpture:

It has great sculpture of Western chalukyan and early kaktiyan era.

The main sanctum sanctorum of the temple (garbha gudi) has great sculptures. It has one one of the oldest and early form of Nataraja sculptures of telugu land !!

(The above is pic of Bhimeshwara temple at Vemulawada, whose architecture resembles Thanjavur’s Brihadiswara alayam/ big temple).

(The above one is am old photo of main Sri Raja Rajeswara temple complex taken during late 1930s , it has typical western chalukyan and Kaktiyan style, which is a mixture of both nagara and dravidian styles, similar to that era temples in Srisailam, Mahabalipuram, alampuram, etc.. and later in 1950s, Dravidan style gopurams were constructed on these).

Puranic Significance :

In Bhavishyottara Purana, it is said that Surya gets his disease cured by worshiping Shiva in Rajarajeshwara kshetram, present day Vemulawada.

Hence in Puranas Vemulawada is praised as “Bhaskara Kshetram” , “RajaRajeshwara Kshetram”!!

Also, the great grandson of Indra, had got freedom from the curse after excavating the Shiva linga from Dharmagundam here and praying to it!!

It is said that, he was the first one to build the temple for Lord RajaRajeshwara here.

It is one of the few Siva temples of the country having similar name for Lord Siva and Goddess Parvathi. In Vemulawada , Siva is known as “Sri Rajarajeshwara “, while Parvati is known as ‘Sri Rajarajeshwari” . Only Ujjaini has similar tradition where Parvati and Siva having almost similar names !!

Concept of Hari-Hara Kshetram: Talking about Vemulawada one should not skip this important topic of Hari Hara abedha, the unity of lord Vishnu and Lord Siva!!

Fig: A daily ritual of Pallaki seva for presiding Saiva and Vaishnava deities.

Fig : The chariots of Sri Rama and Sri Rajarajeshwara during rama navami celebrations

It would be incomplete and insane to skip the discussion of Hari-Hara concept relating to Vemulawada. The guardian deity of the shrine / Kshetra palaka of Vemulawada is “Ananta Padmanabhaswamy “ , a form of Vishnu.

The pallaki seva (palanquin) is done to both Sri Rajarajeshwara swamy and Anantapadmanabhswamy on daily basis. There is a local folk lore that , once Siva pallaki was taken without Vishnu Pallaki, and Siva pallaki had became so heavy that no group of strong people could lift it, people were able to lift it only when they brought Vishnu pallaki along !! This Siva Kesava abedha is so strong that, even in Most important festival for Saivism- Maha Shivarathri, there will be great procession of chariots of both Shiva and Vishnu !! And also During Most important Vaishnava Festivals- Vaikunta Ekadasi and SriRamaNavami, both Shiva and Vishnu chariots and palanquins are grandly taken out for procession. During Sriramanavami, the chariot of Padmanabhaswamy is substituted by that of Sri Sita Lakshmana Sametha Ramachandra Swamy !!

During the time of early kakatiyas, there were stiff wars between Saiva and vaishnava cults in South India , and the Chalukyas and Kakatiyas encouraged peace between them by popularizing the concept of hari-hara tatvam, the unity of both Hari and Hara ( Vishnu and Siva). They popularized this in literature and temples !!

Vemulawada temple is foremost among such temples and till date stands uniquely among all of the hundreds of hari-hara kshetrams in south india, with its practice. Yes, here in Vemulavada it is not called Hari-hara Kshetram , for just the presence of Deities of both from Shaivism and vaishnavism… It is one of the rarest temples , where Both Siva and Vishnu are equally revered and almost all festivals of both Vaishnavism and Saivism are officially celebrated.

Special “Mokku” (solemn vow):

The temple is known for its special mokku called “Kode mokku”, where devotees after having blessed with their wishes, bring Kode/ ox , do pradakshina/parikrama around sanctum with it and tie the ox to a pillar in front of temple !!

And also, devotees offer jaggery as “tulaa bhaaram” (equivalent weight ) to deity.

Place of Telugu Gods , Telugu Festivals and local arts:

It is one of the few ancient temples, where almost all gods revered by Telugus are present. And almost all telugu festivals are grandly and officially celebrated in the temple.

Take any telugu festival - it will be an important festival of the Vemulawada Temple. The famous telugu song -Googlu pooche googulu kaache is a native folk song in and around vemulawaada !!

Apart from extremely popular festivals like Sivarathri, Sri ramanavami, Vaikunta Ekadasi, dasara, bonalu and Bathukamma, there are slew of many other important festivals magnificently celebrated in this land of temples.

Be it bathukamma, be it Vijaya Dasami, Sankranthi, Ugadi, Deepaavali, Vinayaka Chaviti, Vinayaka navarathri utsavam, Holi, Krishnashtami, Varalakshmi vratam, Rakhi Pournami, Hanuman jayanthi, Vata Savitri vratam, Subrahmanya Sasti, narasimha Jayanthi, maasa shivarathri, Sankatahara chaviti, Sankara jayanthi, Dhanurmasam, Sravana masotsavam, Karthikamasotsavam, etc

Not to forget grand Bonalu (a 365 day affair in vemulawada, again a very rare thing), Even before Medaram jathara people visit Vemulawada as a part of custom !!

And even more surprsingly the “TYAGA RAJA ARADHANA UTSAVAM” is also part of temple’s important vaidic festivals.. Tygaraja aradhana is being conducted in Vemulawada from past 66 years as a major cultural event for almost all classical, semi-classical art forms like - Gana kacheri, nrityam, natyam, natakam, hari-katha, bhakti sangeetam, upanyasam, etc !! The Aradhana utsavams continue for 5 days. Many stalwarts of Music like Ghantasala garu, P B Srinivas garu, P. Susselamma , etc have attended these utsavams as special guests.

(Every year, The temple authority does a long drive to select nearly 500 to 600 budding artists from Telangana regions to perform at these Tyagaraja aradhana utsavams. From Adilabad to Madhira in Khammam, performers of various arts are invited. Vemulawada town and and near by agraharam have quite a few classical arts performers).

Many local folk arts in northern Telangana have started or based in Vemulawada. The temple also supports most of them.

Bathukamma here in Vemulawada has a special significance as it is celebrated only for 7 days unlike 9 days in rest of Telangana. The seventh day is grandly celebrated as Saddula bathukamma or Pedda bathukamma in Vemulawada..

Almost all important gods of telugu people from Grama devatas- Pochamma , yellamma to many important gods in Saiva, Vaishnava and Shakti traditions are present here. Even there are deities of Buddhist and Jain pantheon !! You can have Dakshinamurthy to Vittalanatha. From Bala Tripura sundari to Andalamma you can find almost all important Telugu Gods here !!

Rituals:

Unlike all other Saiva Temples in Telugu country, Vemulawada temple follows rituals as per “Smartha Aagamam” . Also, for Ananta Padmanabhaswamy temple, Sri Sitaramaswamy temple and Venugopala swamy temples, the rituals are followed as per “Paancha raathra Agamam”.

Added to this there are many folk rituals that are still in vogue and practiced in parallel with these agamic and vaidic rituals. Prominent ones being Bonalu and other being bathukamma festival.

(the 365 day bonalu in Vemulawada to baddi pochamma ammavaru)

It is one of the few temples where grama devata, Baddi pochamma , is offered Bonalu/ grama devata aradhana for all 365 days in a year.. And it is also a unique place where people of various villages pay respects to grama devata (village deity) of non-native village !!

There is a special ritual on Sri Rama Navami, where people, cutting across age , gender do marry lord Shiva after the celestial marriage of Sita and Rama. Many pilgrims across south India participate in this event and these people are called “Shiva Sattulu/ Shiva Shaktulu”.

See the following video about siva shakthi tradition .

Many devotees of central and northern telangana first visit Vemulwada as “toli mokku” (initial vow) before going to Medaram jatara !!

Other temples in the temple town:

Apart from Sri Raja Rajeshwara swamy main temple complex, there are many other ancient temples in the town , all of which come under Vemulawada Devastanams:

  1. Bhimeswara Alayam (bigger than main temple sanctum!!)
  2. Nagareswara Alayam
  3. Kedareswara Alayam
  4. Baddi Pochamma Alayam
  5. Mahalaksmi Alayam
  6. Venugopala Swamy alayam

On the outskirts of the town , we have

Medieval era Nampally Narasimha swamy alayam, Kalyana venkateshwara swamy Alayam and a modern theme based temple on hill of nampally !! Nampally Narasimhaswamy alayam also comes under Vemulawada devastanams.

In Modern era:

Pedala Devudu or Poor man’s God is how many describe Rajanna / Sri Raja rajeswara swamy signifying the strong spiritual relation between common masses and main deity!!

It is also referred as Tirupati of Telangana !!

(the increased traffic every year, made temple authorities to reduce the temple lake for parking and other cultural programs) .

The temple has donated a lot for the development of other temples in the region like Basara Saraswathi temple, Kaleshwaram- Kaleshwara-Mukteeswara temple, etc..

The temple was also active in charity just like any other major pilgrim centre, it had funded a significant amount in building and maintaining SRR government degree and PG college in Karimnagar apart from Sanskrit and music schools and colleges in Vemulawada. The community function halls / Kalyana mandapams in Karimnagar, Jagityala, Siricilla and Korutla towns are run by the Vemulawada devastanams. The devastanam runs a Homeopathic hospital and a small primary health care center. Donates lakhs of rupees for development of temple town of Vemulawada. It runs free bus trips during Siva rathri Jathara every year. From this year, the temple is also running free bus trips from bus station to temple complex within the town.

It is one of the most busiest temples of telugu land. Srisailam and Vemulawada are said to be the busiest and most visited Siva temples in telugu region. Infact, it is one of the few most busy temples, which doesn’t close in the afternoon (Just like Tirumala Venkanna and Vijayawada kanaka durga temples).

Transport:

Vemulawada used to be the only interior village in whole of Telangana, where there are good road transport facilities for almost all major cities and towns in central and north Telangana apart from Hyderabad. There are buses for every 10 minutes to Vemulawada from Karimnagar , Siricilla and Korutla , while there are buses for every 15 to 20 minutes to Hyderabad , Hanumakonda , Warangal and Siddipeta. There are also significant amount of buses from Kamareddy, Jagityala, Suryapeta, Nizamabad , Ramagundam and Janagama . Once Hyderabad - Karimnagar railway line is completed, Vemulawada will be connected via railway route.

Near By attractions:

Nampally gutta Narasimha swamy temple, nampally dasavatharam temple, Siricilla textile town, Siricilla Venkateshwara swamy temple, Kondagattu Anjaneya swamy temple, Agraharam Anjaneya swamy temple, Nallagonda Narasimhaswamy temple, Karimnagar - Elagandula Fort, Mid manair , upper manair and Lower manair dams.

Best days to visit:

Winter and rainy are better seasons to visit the temple, as water scarcity will be more during summer.

For people who want to avoid rush, it is better to visit temple on wednesdays and thursdays that have no holidays. Or visit on Saturdays that are not part of any long weekends or festivals. better to avoid Mondays , Sundays and Fridays.

(the nampally gutta hill near vemulawada )

What is a temple for Jews?

That depends. For orthodox Jews, thete has only ever been one “temple”, the Beit HaMikdash in Jerusalem (destroyed in 70 CE). Since then, there has been no such thing as a “Jewish temple”.

The Reform movement, however, took to referring to synagogues as “temples”. Thus, non-orthodox Jews often call their synagogues “temples” and many Reform synagogues have names like “Temple Beth Israel”, “Temple Eitz HaChaim” etc.

Why is Swayambhunath called the Monkey Temple?

There is a legend behind why Swayambhunath in Kathmandu is called the 'Monkey Temple'. It's all to do with a group of monkeys that have lived in the northwest part of the Swayambhunath temple complex for generations.

Mythology. According to Swayambhu Purana, the entire valley was once filled with an enormous lake, out of which grew a lotus. The valley came to be known as Swayambhu, meaning "Self-Created." The name comes from an eternal self-existent flame (svyaṃbhu) over which a sūpa was later built.

What did Sumerians call their large temples?

The standard word for temple was é-gal — literally just “big house”.

Sumerian can be an amazingly simple and straightforward language.

“Man” is just lu. So “king” is lugal, “big man”.

“Dog” is just ur. So “lion” is ur-maḫ, “grand dog”.

(I don’t have access to any Sumerian materials at the moment — this is all from memory.)

Where is the Mookambika Devi temple?

Mookambika temple is located at Kollur, Karnataka. This is an ancient temple that has a lot of history attached to it. The temple can be reached easily from the states of Kerala, Tamil Nadu, and Karnataka.

Being situated in the land between Gokarna and Kanyakumari, believed to be created by sage Parashurama, it finds a spot in the 108 Durga Temples in the ancient Kerala. The temple is also one among the 108 Shiva temples in Kerala, since Lord Shiva is also considered to be present in the temple.

What is Buddhist temple called?

It really depends on the school, tradition or country as to what it’s called. Names like gonpa or ling (Tibetan Buddhism), Vihara (Theravadin), Wat (Thailand, Laos and Cambodia) are some of the names used for Buddhist temples in the native tongues. In English they are simply called Buddhist temples and this is not disrespectful.

In the Medak District of Telangana state, there are two old Kala Bhairava Temples:

  1. Kala Bhairava Temple in Kajipalli Medak Mandal.
  2. Sri Kala Bhairava Swamy Temple, located Opposite to Mediciti hospital, 5 km from Medchal

Usually, ‘Bhairava’ or ‘kalabhairava’ Diety won’t be having any temple built and the god is considered to be as a village protector. The idol will be placed at entrance of the village. He is considered to be one of the ‘polimera devudu’.

Regarding the Kajipalli Temple, the 8 forms of Bhairavas are placed and the modernisation of this very old temple is in progress. This temple was in woods and not known fro many years alike many temples like Alladurg in the Medak district.

In the year 2008 the old temple was discovered in disfigured state standing on a stone surrounded by 4 small pillars in Kajipally vilage which is situated 9 kilometers away from Medak district. The temple was abandoned for the last 300 to 500 years as per the local villagers.

The AshtaBhairava Temple is designed in a unique-ness with the main deity being the Shiv Ling being seated in the centre of the Ashtabhairava seated on the eight sides in a octagon shaped. The main deity i.e., the Shiva Lingam is a Panchamukha will be planned at Gharbhalayam which would be completely made of stone carved temple occupying 25’ ft height, 25’ ft width, & 25’ft length. Construction the main deity of Panchamukha Shiva Lingam is planned with architectural beauty.

The architecture of the temple is designed in such a way that it should significance its uniqueness in the modern era. Above Gharbhalayam, the main temple gopuram would be 48’ fts in height, whose architecture reflects the North & South India Tradition. It is being planned in such a way that it reflects the majestic grandiose of the North Indian architecture and the simplicity of South Indian architecture.

The above image depicts the ongoing temple structure.

About the temple in Medchal, it is known as ‘BhiravaGutta’. Along with the main deity, the other Hindu deities like RamaLingeshwara etc. are also present.

Along with these two temples, there are few other locally famous Bhairava tempels in the Medak district as I have mentioned earlier, the god is considered to be one of the village protector and the idol of him will be having no temple.

What temples to visit in Hyderabad?

1.chilkur balaji temple, this temple is also popularly known as “Visa Balaji temple”.

2. Peddamma Temple is an Hindu temple located at Jubilee Hills in Hyderabad. It is very famous during the festive season of Bonaalu.

3.Birla Mandir is a Hindu temple, built on a 280 feet high hillock called Naubath Pahad on a 13 acres plot. The construction took 10 years and was opened in 1976 by Swami Ranganathananda of Ramakrishna Mission.

4.The Jagannath Temple in Hyderabad, a modern temple built by the Odia community of the city of Hyderabad dedicated to the Hindu God Jagannath. The temple located near Banja

1.chilkur balaji temple, this temple is also popularly known as “Visa Balaji temple”.

2. Peddamma Temple is an Hindu temple located at Jubilee Hills in Hyderabad. It is very famous during the festive season of Bonaalu.

3.Birla Mandir is a Hindu temple, built on a 280 feet high hillock called Naubath Pahad on a 13 acres plot. The construction took 10 years and was opened in 1976 by Swami Ranganathananda of Ramakrishna Mission.

4.The Jagannath Temple in Hyderabad, a modern temple built by the Odia community of the city of Hyderabad dedicated to the Hindu God Jagannath. The temple located near Banjara hills Road no.12 in Hyderabad is famous for its annual Rathyatra festival attended by thousands of devotees.

5. Sanghi temple stands beautifully on the hillock ‘Paramanand Giri’. Built in the Chola-Chalukya style of architecture, the temple is a place worth visiting. This temple was built in the year of 1991 which was completed in a just 18 months.

6.Ashtalakshmi Temple is very famous temple of Goddess Lakshmi Maa, is located between Dilsukh Nagar and LB Nagar. At this temple we can observe eight forms of Goddess Lakshmi: Adilakshmi, Aishwaryalakshmi, Santanalakshmi, Dhanalakshmi, Dhanyalakshmi, Gajalakshmi, Vijayalakshmi, and Varalakshmi. with small inner temples. This temple is maintained neat, peaceful and has a good premises with wide area for parking, prasada distribution.

What is the significance of a temple near Hyderabad called Chilukuru Balaji?

He is called a Visa God because people who are going abroad bring their passports and put them near his feet for safe travel.

Not only that, but people wanting to get their visa approved also come to take Balaji's blessings so it gets approved faster.

One can first visit the temple and do 11 pradakshinas for their wishes to come true. Once their wishes are true, they should come again for 108 pradakshinas.

It has a very divine atmosphere and is also near to Hyderabad city (20–25 kms).

How do I reach the Kukke Subramanya Temple from Hyderabad?

You can travel from by train from Hyderabad to Subramanya Road station. Or fly from Hyderabad to Mangalore and then take a bus to Kukke Subramanya.

By Bus: Hyderabad->Bengaluru->Subramanya road

Kukke Subramanya has its own railway station. The nearest airport is at Mangalore. Bus services are available to and from the neighboring cities at regular intervals.

Local city buses are available from most nearby cities and towns to Kukke Subramanya.

How to reach Kukke Subramanya by train

The Kukke Subramanya railway station is located around 7 km from the city center. You can easily find a can outside the railway station.

Local transport in Kukke Subramanya

Regular as well as deluxe buses are available here to travel within the city. Taxis and autorickshaws can be hired for transportation to and from the railway station.

Why is the Brihadishvara Temple called a shadowless temple?

Because —it is said => ARCHITECTURALLY it is So Brilliantly constructed —that the Shadow of the 216 feet TOWER will not FALL on the Ground -on any day -at any Time -in a Year.

How do I go to the Shrishailam Temple from Hyderabad?

Two options to consider:

  1. By car
  2. By bus

If you try 1st option, which is the best option, then you can enjoy the drive thru the forest. You can also visit north gate of Srisailam “Umamaheshwaram” temple. You can stop at different location to enjoy nature. You can visit places like Mallelateertham water falls (if time permits for you). The roads are too good. Drive thru the forest (around 60–80kms) is awesome (beware of too many speed breakers on the road in the middle of the forest) You can stop in the middle of the forest and have lunch at the designated stopping points where govt has made arrange

Two options to consider:

  1. By car
  2. By bus

If you try 1st option, which is the best option, then you can enjoy the drive thru the forest. You can also visit north gate of Srisailam “Umamaheshwaram” temple. You can stop at different location to enjoy nature. You can visit places like Mallelateertham water falls (if time permits for you). The roads are too good. Drive thru the forest (around 60–80kms) is awesome (beware of too many speed breakers on the road in the middle of the forest) You can stop in the middle of the forest and have lunch at the designated stopping points where govt has made arrangements to sit and eat. The vehicles are allowed from 6 am till 9 pm.

Route:

Hyderabad - Tukkuguda ORR Exit - Kadtal - Amangal - Veldanda - Dindi - Mannanur - Srisailam forest ghat road - Domalapenta - Eegalapenta - Patalaganga (Srisailam dam) - Sundipenta - Srisailam.

Here is good article for further reference: Highway - the only way !

For 2nd option, there are number of bus services running from Hyderabad to Srisailam (from MGBS and JBS). If you take late night buses you will be stopped at the Mannanur check post till 6 am.
